Overall, Far Cry 6 is worth playing for its world and gameplay freedom, but it lacks the strong story and character moments that make a Far Cry game truly memorable.

This game took me a little over 50 hours to fully complete. If you are familiar with the previous entries, this might feel a little bit like Thor: Ragnarok felt after the first two Thor movies.

First off, the story starts very strong. It is intense and interesting. It quickly falls off after the prologue to make space for [i]your[/i] gameplay. You can play stealth or loud, you can make sick homemade weapons or stick to the classics. Great customization options, too. A bit tiring to run around the map to collect stuff for upgrades, but I get the point of it.

The map is [b]huge[/b]. And vibrant and colorful. Some animals, too. A lot to do, a lot to collect. Environment is destructible on a scale I haven't seen before in the Far Cry series.

Back to story – it quickly falls off and has problems getting up again. It feels like there's too many [b]comic relief[/b] characters and it takes down the classical serious tone of FC. It's sometimes cringe, sometimes it feels woke-forced (not too much, but still odd). And then you are introduced to [i]another[/i] pile of cheerful companions, so unfit for the Far Cry world.

At that point, you play only for the [b]gameplay[/b], which is [i]extremely[/i] enjoyable.

There is no plot armor in this game, some characters undergo deep transformation, and things happen. [b]Far Cry 6 – Explosive, Emotional, and Full of Charisma[/b]

[i]Far Cry 6[/i] is a powerful and high-octane open-world shooter that delivers everything fans of the series love — and then some. From its lush Caribbean-inspired setting to its deeply personal story, the game strikes a satisfying balance between wild action and genuine emotional stakes.

Yara is a rich, vibrant, and brutal island. Ruled by a ruthless dictator, it creates a sharp contrast between tropical beauty and political oppression. Exploring Yara—whether on foot, in vehicles, or using improvised guerilla gear—is constantly rewarding, with rebellion simmering beneath every mission and region.

Gameplay-wise, [i]Far Cry 6[/i] excels through freedom and creativity. Whether you're sneaking through enemy checkpoints, launching explosive assaults, or crafting DIY “resolver” weapons, the game empowers you to play your way. The resolver system adds personality to every encounter, making combat feel uniquely yours.

Giancarlo Esposito delivers an unforgettable performance as Anton Castillo. His cold intensity, presence, and emotional tension with his son make him one of the strongest villains in the franchise. As Dani Rojas, your journey from reluctant fighter to revolutionary hero feels personal and compelling.

Side missions, hidden secrets, and guerilla tasks keep the world feeling alive. Liberating towns, rescuing civilians, hunting VIP targets, and helping locals all build a sense of active rebellion. The Amigo system—with its quirky and often hilarious animal companions—adds charm and tactical variety to combat.

Visually, the game is stunning. Lush landscapes, detailed environments, and great weather effects make Yara incredibly immersive. The sound design—gunfire, wildlife, music—perfectly captures the intensity and atmosphere of a guerilla uprising.

[i]Far Cry 6[/i] is explosive, emotional, stylish, and full of personality. For fans of open-world shooters and story-driven chaos, it is absolutely worth playing.

[b] Far Cry 6 [/b] is a game full of mixed feelings. On one side, it offers a huge and beautiful open world that is a joy to explore. The tropical islands, detailed cities, and wild areas look great, and there is always something new to discover. There are many collectibles and side activities, which can keep you busy for hours. In terms of size and variety, the game does very well.

On the other side, the story and main missions are weak. The idea of the villain and his son had a lot of potential, but in the end it feels wasted. The missions are average, often repetitive, and do not bring strong emotions. The whole story also feels heavy with political correctness, which kills the darker and more serious mood that should be here.

Gameplay is still fun thanks to a big choice of weapons and the freedom to finish missions in many ways. Trying different tactics and using gadgets gives some good moments, but it is also clear that the series is stuck in the same formula and does not surprise anymore.

Far Cry 6 is a game to enjoy for its world and freedom, but it misses the spirit, character, and strong story. For me, it is good for exploration and action, but not a game I will remember for its story.

[h2] Short version of my review - [/h2]
7/10 game. Beautiful visuals, okay-ish open-world, satisfying gunplay, and a very good lore with a somewhat weak execution. Good for your first playthrough, but not for replaying. Buy it if you get it on sale, and you are not a huge fan of dense open-worlds and would be content with driving around empty roads, and you love some gunplay action.

But compared to other Far Cry games, like FC3 and 4, this is not even close. But if you're a first timer, you'd enjoy it tho. And there's nothing this game has what other FC games haven't. This is just some sorta copy-paste from previous titles with a new lore.

[h2]Long Version:[/h2]

1. Graphics and Sound - [b]9/10[/b].
Sound design is very good, and it really creates the sense of revolution that the lore seems to portray. Graphics are really good, colours are saturates, in a good way, of course, and the whole world feels colourful, which creates the lore even more chilling. The devs have put color science to a good use!

2. Gameplay and mechanics - [b]8.5/10[/b]
Gunplay is awesome, every shot feels satisfying. Driving is very good, responsive and asthetically realistic. First person animations are also good, but they could have been better, especially those animations in which Dani is holding a gun. In terms of combat, melee is limited to machatte kills and basic slash. Guns have variety, but you get limited ammo, and hence ammo conservation is important in large-scale combat scenarios, which also feels good and amusing. The weapon and ride upgrades are also good, and I enjoyed upgrading my guns and supremos very much. But almost all mechanics were also present in the previous FC games, so nothing new here.

3. Environment and Open world - [b]7.5/10[/b]
The environment is mostly forests with roads all over. You'd enjoy driving for a few hours, but then you'd slowly lose interest. The open world feels very empty, with some Castillo's soldiers here and there, some prisoners, and some trucks. If you are a fan of open worlds, this isn't for you. The destructible environments, like trees, bushes and other stuff look good, and overall ambience is good. But you'd miss the open-world feeling, as there is nothing in it.

4. Story and lore - [b]6/10[/b]
As I said earlier, the base lore is quite good - A dictator taking control of a country, and revolutionaries trying to overthrow him (this is just the basic, if you wanna know about the lore, search it up on the internet). The game writer did a good job, but the narrative structure doesn't do it much justice. I mean, this lore could have made some really great stories, but the overall narrative execution was perhaps the weakest part of this game. The cutscenes are somewhat good, they look cinematic. But I do think they might have been made better. But overall, you'd enjoy the story if you are not going for a truly real experience. The main antagonist doesn't care even if you capture every single checkpost and base, and there are quite a few such things which can break immersion, but still, it's manageable.

[h3]VERDICT:[/h3]
The game has its share of flaws, but the overall lore, mechanics and the ambience of the game hooked me till the end. But is the game worth its full price? I'd say no. Buy it in sales, when the price drops by more than 60%. I also purchased the game for ~$7 in a sale (INR 599), thanks to regional pricing in India. And what I got was an immense value for my money.

[b]A respectable 7/10.[/b]

[h1]Far Cry 6 Review[/h1]

[hr]
[h1]In One Word - Average[/h1]

[hr]
[h1]What Works[/h1]

Graphics are gorgeous and the world is nice to look at

Voice acting is solid and companions are likable

Big map with plenty to poke at

Performance is better now than at launch and I ran into very few bugs

[hr]
[h1]What Does Not[/h1]

Story is mediocre and the ending is a letdown

Missions and side content blend together and rarely surprise

Exploration often feels empty and unrewarding

Collectibles feel like padding for achievement hunters more than meaningful content

[hr]
[h1]World and Exploration[/h1]
Yara is pretty and fun to roam at first. After a while it feels wide but thin. You will clear icons, loot things, and move on without many memorable moments.

[hr]
[h1]DLCs[/h1]
The villain DLCs sound great on paper, but each one is basically the same loop with a different coat of paint. Repetitive and not worth the price. [h1]Combat and Gameplay[/h1]
Shoots well enough and the toys are flashy, but it rarely evolves. If you have played any recent Far Cry, you have basically played this one.

[hr]
[h1]Achievements[/h1]
Mostly grindy but doable. The standout pain is “Oh No You Don’t,” which requires killing three insurgent leaders and is gated weekly. No quick workaround anymore, so it becomes a waiting game in a single player title. Not fun.

If this is your first Far Cry or you only dabbled in one of the older ones, you may enjoy the spectacle and the map checklist. If you have history with the series and expect the next step up, you will probably be disappointed.

Far Cry 6 is fine, just not exciting. Pretty visuals and decent performances carry it, but the story, mission design, and DLCs drag it down. Newcomers on a discount might have a good time. Everyone else can skip or wait for a deep sale.

Far Cry 6 – A Beautiful but Broken Revolution

I’ve played every Far Cry game since the beginning, and to me, Far Cry 2 and 3 are still the best in the series. They had a raw intensity and sense of freedom that made the franchise what it is. Sadly, Far Cry 6 feels like a big step backward a flashy open world that looks amazing but plays terribly.

The Good

Let’s start with what works. The world of Yara is visually stunning easily one of the best-looking environments Ubisoft has ever created. The lighting, detail, and atmosphere make the island feel alive at first glance.
The soundtrack is solid, and Giancarlo Esposito’s performance as Antón Castillo brings some much-needed personality to the story. When the game actually works, chaotic firefights and explosions still deliver that signature Far Cry energy.

The Problems

Unfortunately, almost everything else falls apart fast.

1. Dumb and Broken AI
NPCs and enemies act like they’ve never been tested. Enemies ignore you in plain sight, react late, or glitch into walls. Civilians just wander aimlessly with no life to them. For a game set in a supposed revolution, it feels surprisingly empty and soulless.

2. Outposts and Red Zones Are a Disaster
One of my biggest frustrations  and many players agree  is how inconsistent the control zones are. Some red areas on the map can’t even be cleared properly. Others stay red even after you’ve fought everyone there. And disabling alarms sometimes triggers bugs that break the area entirely.
In an open world game built on freedom and territory control, this completely kills the motivation to explore.

3. Terrible Flying and Vehicle Controls
Flying planes and helicopters should be exciting  instead, it feels like a fight against the controls. The handling is stiff, unresponsive, and ruins any sense of fun. Even driving doesn’t feel smooth, which is shocking for a game this large.

4. Weapons Feel Weak and Unrewarding
The guns sound and feel like toys. There’s no impact when shooting  headshots or body shots, it all feels the same. Enemies drop with no weight or reaction, making combat dull and repetitive.
And the weapon upgrade system? Overcomplicated and unrewarding. I spent more time in menus trying to understand attachments than actually enjoying the firefights.

5. Full of Bugs and Technical Issues
From outpost alarms bugging out to enemies spawning inside objects, Far Cry 6 constantly breaks immersion. It’s hard to enjoy when you’re never sure whether something’s a feature or just another glitch.

Compared to the Classics

Far Cry 3 and 4 had something this game doesn’t soul. They gave players tension, choice, and that gritty sense of survival. Far Cry 6 looks bigger and louder, but it’s missing the essence that made the older games unforgettable. It’s overdesigned, underpolished, and far less satisfying.

Final Verdict

Far Cry 6 could have been a great evolution of the series, but instead, it’s a beautiful shell filled with bugs, broken systems, and lifeless design.
If you loved Far Cry 3 or 4.you’ll likely find this one disappointing. It’s a game that wants to give you freedom but ends up restricting it at every turn.

There is a Steam achievement for beating the game - not to any level of completion, but just to reach the final cutscene of the story - and it has an 11.1% achievement rate. I am 0% surprised. That should really tell you all you need to know. I didn't even encounter most of the bugs that people are talking about, and I have no questions as to why so few people are reaching the end credits.

For starters, the game design is nonsensical and inconsistent. A little microcosm of an example: in the western and central sections of the main map, your missions are pretty standard fare "follow the golden diamond on your map" types of quests. Go to a place, kill some dudes, hit E on a computer, etc. Quest marker on everything. But in the eastern section, there are several quests where you don't get a diamond, and have to hunt and find your objective. They reference landmarks on the map to tell you where to look, which would be fine... except those landmarks' names don't appear until you reach the absolute most zoomed in level, and have to pan around searching for the stupid things. One of the missions even gives you an image on your character's phone. Of a map. With your quest targets marked. But you still don't get an in-game quest marker. Uh, okay then. It really makes it feel arbitrary when it does or does not give you these quest markers until you realize it's probably because it was a different team working on that section of the game, and they didn't check back enough with the other teams. Sloppy, sloppy design.

The design would be excusable if the story was great. Unfortunately, the writing is bland and generic. You are a guerilla. There is a dictator, and he has some generals. That's literally all you need to know. Whatever storyline you drew up in your head? Yeah, that's the exact storyline of Far Cry 6. This could maybe be redeemed if the characters were interesting enough to make up for it. Except... they're actually somehow [i]worse[/i] than the plot itself. Most of the allied characters are bland caricatures of some one to three word cliche. "Badass woman" is present and accounted for. "Eccentric engineer"? Check. "Gay drag queen"? You betcha! The villains are flatter still. There's absolute ZERO villain nuance. The bad guys are just completely, comically evil. Picture any bad thing a person can do. Yep! At least one of the main bad guys are doing that! Previous Far Cry games tossed in some moral quandaries as well. Far Cry 3 had you asking, "What is all this killing doing to me?" Far Cry 4 asked, "Am I really picking the lesser of two (or I guess three) evils?" Far Cry 5 even had the stones to ask, "What if this guy is actually right? Do the ends justify the means?" "Nah," says some Ubisoft writer somewhere, "no time for that here! Your allies are always in the right, and your enemies are always in the wrong. Nice, neat, moral black and white, just how you and your simple gamer mind like it, right? Now quick, let's use that to push an agenda!"

Which... listen, I'm all for games making a statement. If you've built a platform and you want to use it to speak about something that's important to you, then I say go for it. But holy hell, has Far Cry 6 done it in a profoundly jarring and disingenuous way. To start, the game is set in "I Can't Believe It's Not Cuba!" No part of the story takes place in America (unless you count a single cutscene in the secret ending). Yet, we've still found a way to call Americans racist two separate times in the span of the main questline alone? Come on, now. Well, okay. It's annoying, but it's two lines of dialogue in a big game. The big problem is the ENTIRE THIRD OF THE GAME that is just... wall to wall bad, because they wrote around trying to shoehorn trans representation in. Look, I get it. You want to address current issues, and make people feel seen. But, this guy is in the middle of a war, where people are being killed, abducted, tortured, and subjected to human experimentation (remember, no villain nuance). So why the hell is his main concern how hard it is to be trans? Don't even get me started on the showdown with the general of that section. (spoiler describes the contents of that scene) [spoiler]She misgenders the trans character, so said character's girlfriend [i]brutally guns her down on live TV[/i]. Not to mention that disdain for LGBT is not a character trait the villain has ever shown at this point. It just happens out of nowhere for this scene, because they want to make the statement with their one-dimensional villains that evil = misgendering, and want to brutalize a character who does it.[/spoiler] It plays out like it was written by a frustrated middle-schooler, not a triple A game studio. Now don't get me wrong - representation can absolutely be done right. Kim Kitsuragi from Disco Elysium is an awesome character, and is far more concerned with being a good detective than being a homosexual (in a game about being a detective, imagine!) despite being both of those things. Even when matters of a character's sexuality/identity take center-stage, it can be done well when that's important to the plot - see Kanji Tatsumi, my literal favorite character from the Persona series. Far Cry 6, though, misses this mark HARD.

Okay... so the game design is sloppy and inconsistent. The story and characters are flat at best, and the picture of abject cringeworthiness at worst. Surely the gameplay makes up for some of it, right? ...right? Well, a little... maybe. The gameplay is... fine, I guess, at least at first. It's still a step below other Far Cry titles, but it's not unplayable. There's an extra incentive when clearing out bases for stealth and picking enemies off like the guerilla you are. On paper, there's also an emphasis on picking "the right tool for the right job", which comes in the form of different ammo types for different enemies. However. The first ammo type you unlock is armor piercing, and you learn pretty quickly that you'll never need nor want to use anything else, except for maybe blast rounds to fight vehicles. Why? Because even the weakest guns in the game with armor piercing rounds are perfectly capable of killing any enemy in the game with one shot to the head, at any range that will ever matter. In fact, it's the only real way to kill enemies - if you hit them in the body, it can take up to 20 shots instead, depending on what gun and ammo type you're using. Slap a suppressor on that thing, and you can take down entire squads of the absolute lobotomy survivors they added to this game as enemy combatants before any of them ever notice you're ten feet from them. This is compounded by the fact that unless you're in a restricted area, you can just holster your gun and run right next to the soldiers without them doing anything, to make this game very, very, very unchallenging. Oh, also you get an ultimate ability in the form of a superpower backpack. You'll almost never need to use it, but you've got it. If you put the medical one on, you'll completely trivialize the game, since whenever you go down you can just pop your ult and get right back up. The silver lining to all this is that, because the game isn't really much of a challenge, you do feel like a total badass, clearing through hordes of soldiers without any trouble at all... at least at first. But after achieving your full potential in the first 15% of the game and with no real character progression outside of gear, it quickly descends into a boring slog for the rest. Also - how the hell did they make the TANKS in this game so clunky and impotent that they're just not worth the effort to drive? Tanks in a shooter are supposed to be awesome!

All in all - this game is just not in any way worth the time, effort, or money you'd be sinking into it. If you really want to run the gauntlet to be part of the 11.1%, I can't stop you. But now, you can never say I didn't warn you.
